topic_knowledge_points: Substrings P[i..j], prefixes P[0..i], suffixes P[i..m−1]; null string length 0; alphabet Σ typically finite.
STL string supports size, empty, operator[], at, insert, append, erase, substr, find, c_str, iterators, comparisons, concatenation, I/O.
DP applies when problems decompose into overlapping subproblems with optimal substructure.
Matrix chain-product: define Ni,j = min over k of Ni,k + Nk+1,j + d_i d_{k+1} d_{j+1}, with Ni,i = 0; bottom-up O(n^3) time.
Longest Common Subsequence (LCS): L[i,j] = L[i−1,j−1]+1 if xi=yj else max(L[i−1,j], L[i,j−1]); O(nm) time, O(nm) space; reconstruct by backtracking.
Brute force: try all alignments; worst-case O(nm).
Boyer–Moore (simplified): compare right-to-left; last(c) table; jump by m − min(j, 1+last(T[i])); worst-case O(nm+|Σ|), fast in practice on text.
Knuth–Morris–Pratt (KMP): failure function f(j) = length of longest prefix of P that is suffix of P[1..j]; scan once, shifting by f; O(n+m) time.
Huffman coding builds optimal prefix code using a min-priority queue: iteratively merge two least-frequent trees; O(n + d log d) time.
Greedy method: construct solution by locally optimal choices; Huffman coding exhibits greedy-choice property.
Standard trie: ordered tree; edges labeled by characters; external nodes represent set strings; height equals longest string; O(n) nodes with n total length; searching O(dm) where d=|Σ|.
Compressed (Patricia) trie: compress single-child chains; labels are substrings via (i,j,k) or (i,j) references; O(s) nodes for s strings; space-efficient index.
Suffix trie/tree: trie of all suffixes of X$; compact representation uses (i,j) indices into X; supports substring queries in O(m) after O(n) (specialized) build.
Inverted index (search engines): trie on terms → pointers to sorted occurrence lists; multi-term queries via list intersections.
